testimony: Thank you, Chairperson.  The next applicant is Richard Dlamini, number 15 on the list.
Mr Dlamini, what language are you going to speak?  Will you please give us your full names.

Thank you.  You are required to raise your voice a little bit because you are not talking to me alone, you are talking to everyone in this room.  You've talk and speak in such a way that even a person who is at the back there can hear you, do you understand?

Thank you, Chairperson.
	I want you to identify your signature on the Form 1 amnesty application, on page 213.
This document has been shown to you and you've indicated to me there is one mistake on this document and that in paragraph 11(b), is that correct?
When was the first time for you to become aware that there was an attack to be launched on Boipatong?
Prior to the 17th of June 1992, did you attend any meeting where anything in regard to a possible attack on Boipatong was discussed?
I was never present in such a meeting.
Now to the extent that there's a reference to a meeting on the 10th when an order was given, is that what is not in order in that paragraph?
Can the speaker please repeat the question?
To the extent that there is a reference to the 10th of June when an order was given, is that the wrong part of that paragraph?
I beg your pardon, what is a mistake?

The reference to the 10th.  The witness said the first time he became aware of the attack was on the 17th.  The witness said  that the first time he became aware of the attack was on the 17th and he did not go to any meeting on the 10th.
	I also want to show you the answer to paragraph 10(a) ...(intervention)
Could the speaker please move closer to the mike, thank you.

I also want to show you the answer to paragraph 10(a), given in a separate annexure on page 214.  Now the answer has been translated to you on a previous occasion, do you agree with the contents of that paragraph?
Can you in your own words say why did you go to Boipatong and form part of the attack on Boipatong?
When I went to Boipatong, the intention was to face the comrades.  We wanted to drive them away, the comrades who were guarding the place.
Why did you want to chase the comrades away?
We were unable to do anything in the township.  Even our relatives who were residing there in the townships were harassed.
Then I want to show you the request for further particulars on page 216 and your answers on page 218.  These questions and answers were translated to you, do you stand by the answers?
And then I want to refer you to your affidavit, and I will start with your signature on page 223.  Is that your signature?
Do you agree with the contents of that affidavit?
Yes, I agree with the contents.
Can you just briefly state what you did in Boipatong during the night of the attack.
On that night my job was to stab the people there, these comrades.  That was my job.
After you have entered Boipatong, did the comrades run away?
They were scattered all over the township and we kept on chasing them.
Yes, we went into the houses.
Did you stab people in houses?
Yes, some of the comrades were in the shack.  We stabbed them.  Themba shot some of them.
Apart from comrades which one would expect to be relatively young male people, did you attack any other residents of Boipatong?
Yes, there was another man that I attacked.
Approximately how many people did you stab during the attack?
Do you know if the people that you stabbed died?
I am not certain whether they died or not but I wanted to make sure that if I stab a person he or she would just die.
Did you hear any shots being fired in Boipatong?
Did you see anyone of the attackers specifically shoot any person?
Yes, I saw a person from the group of people that I was with.
The first person to shoot at a comrade was Damani, the second one was Themba Mabote who was shooting in the shack.
In your affidavit you make mention about another person in the hostel names Keswa, who is that person?
Sorry, Mr Strydom, I didn't get the interpretation correctly, did he say he shot in a shack or in a house?  Because I heard him say ...(Zulu).
It was in the shack, the shack was in the yard.

The next question was the reference there on page 222 of your affidavit, and I'm going to translate
"I was informed by other residents in the hostel ..."
the name there is:
"... Keswa, to go and fetch a weapon."
This person, Keswa, what are his full names?
I don't know his full names, I only know him as Xhoslele Zingene.
Is that Victor Keswa or not?
Will the speaker please repeat the question?
Is that Victor Keswa, also known as Getisi?
No, that is not the one.  That one is an old man, the one that you are talking about.
After the attack in the hostel on the following day, were you also responsible to burn some of the goods that was taken from Boipatong?
Do you remember who gave you the order to do that or was it out of your own initiative?
Damarra came to my house and I was asleep, he woke me up.
So approximately what time would you say did you start burning goods?
Though I cannot remember the time, I think it was round about eight, between eight and nine.
During the attack, did you see any police or military vehicles in Boipatong?
No, I saw no cars or police.
As far as your knowledge goes, did the police or the Defence Force assist before or during the attack?
No, I know nothing about the assistance before the attack.
Did you see any police or military vehicles after the attack?
Before the attack, did you attend any meeting where Mr Themba Khosa said anything about the possibility of an attack on any township in the Vaal Triangle?
No,  I was never present in such a meeting.
After the attack, did you see Mr Themba Khosa and Humphrey Ndlovu at the hostel?
Did Mr Themba Khosa address a meeting on the 18th of the 19th of June 1992?
On the 18th I cannot remember seeing him addressing a meeting, I only remember on the 19th he addressed a meeting.
Yes, I did attend the meeting.
Did Mr Khosa give any instructions in regard to the burning of loot or bloody clothes?
He never gave that instruction, it's myself who issued that instruction.
You say you are the one who issued the order that items be burnt, I'm asking you at what stage was this?
It was in the morning of the 18th.  Damarra gave me the instruction to tell the people to burn the goods that were taken from Boipatong and that is what I did.
And how did you do this?
I went through the left-hand side.  I was shouting and telling the people that if someone brought something from Boipatong, that should be burnt.
Do you know the policeman that was at the hearing the other day, Peens?
No, I saw him for the very first time here on Friday.  I saw them, the two of them for the first time on Friday.
You also refer then to Rooikop, is that right?
Can the speaker please repeat the question?
You also refer to the other policeman, his surname is Greeff but his nickname is Rooikop?
It's what I heard.  As he was standing here, I heard that he was Rooikop, but I do not know him.
Do you know a person by the name of Andries Matanzima Nosenga?
Yes, I know him, I know Matanzima.
When was the first time for you to meet this person?
Though I cannot remember well, but that was after the attack, months after the attack.
When were you arrested for the Boipatong incident?
I cannot remember the month but I was the last person to be arrested.

Thank you, I've got no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR STRYDOM

I have not questions, thank you.
NO QUESTIONS BY MS PRETORIUS

I have no questions, Mr Chairman.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR DA SILVA
You say that you met Mr Nosenga after the attack on Boipatong, what was noticeable about Mr Nosenga that you remember him?

The reason for me to remember Matanzima, we were sitting at the hostel playing some game called Mlabalala, a guy called Vusi and Spongulwana.  They were washing the cars and they said there was a young man who was speaking Sotho, and I enquired what is it that he was saying there.
	They called us to come and listen to him.  We went to that place.  When we arrived there they communicated in Sotho with him.  They later interpreted to us, they told us that he said he was sent there by the ANC to enquire as how to plant the bombs inside the hostel ...(intervention)
Would you please just slow down so that we can make some notes.  What are the names of these boys that you say came to you?
Myself and the others took him from that place ...(intervention)
Sorry, I didn't catch the name of the person, you said someone and others?
Maybe you said I, it just cut off on the interpretation.  Just repeat your answer please.

I said two gentlemen came, Vusi and Pongulwana.  They came as we were playing a game.  They came to tell us that there was a young man from the township who was there at the place where the two gentlemen were washing the cars.
	We asked them what was he saying, what was it that the young man was saying.  They did not tell us anything but they said we must come with them to listen to this gentleman.  
	We went to that place and they asked him questions in Sotho and they later interpreted to us because we did not understand the Sotho language.  He said he was sent by the African National Congress to come and inspect the place inside the hostel, as to how he can plant the bombs.
	We later took him - we then took him to the IFP Committee.  We handed them over to that committee.  They communicated with him and we left him there.  After some time we heard that he admitted to everything that was said by the two gentlemen.  
	Fortunately he came at a time where there was going to be a conference in Ulundi.  He was then taken - the people who were going to the conference took him with to Ulundi to the conference.  The matters was reported, the others were told about him.  I was not there at that conference.
	They brought him back again.  He stayed there inside the hostel.  As to when did he leave the hostel I do not know.  He was still young at the time and when I saw him here he was a bit older.
You mentioned that you took him to the committee of the IFP in the hostel.
Who in particular did you take him to?
To you your knowledge, Mr Dlamini, was Mr Nosenga only to talk Sotho, was he unable to communicate with yourselves?
Well I put it to you that his Zulu is as good as your Zulu, that he will give evidence in Zulu and that he's not even a Sotho-speaking person.
I don't know about that, you know about that.  All I know is that he was speaking Sotho.
Are you perhaps not mixing up Mr Nosenga with somebody else?
No.  I can see clearly and my mind works very well.  I know that he is the person.
Well what do you say about the fact that he can talk Zulu so fluently, that in fact he's communicating with the interpreters in Zulu and not in Sotho?
Well he's just answered you and he says he is not aware that he can speak Zulu as good as he does.
Mr Dlamini, you've heard the evidence of your co-applicants so far, is that correct?
You've been present throughout these proceedings, is that correct?
Yes, it's only on the 18th where I was not present.
You've heard me put Mr Nosenga's version to the other co-applicants regarding the events that led to the attack and the attack itself, is that correct?
Do you stand then by your denial that Mr Nosenga resided at the hostel prior to the attack and took, and participated in the attack on the night of the 17th of June?
So it is not necessary for me to put to you Mr Nosenga's version, you remember the version and you deny it in its entirety, is that correct?
Can you tell me, what motive would you impugn upon Mr Nosenga for placing himself at the hostel when he was not at the hostel or for participating in the attack, when you claim he did not?
I think this person is lying.  He is a bit confused because of the sentence that he is serving.  He's saying things that did not happen.
I put it to you that insofar as Mr Nosenga's evidence contradicts yours, you are the person who is lying and Mr Nosenga is being open and honest with this Committee.
I am not lying, I'm saying he is the one who is telling the lie.  Where - you are representing him, that is why you are saying I am lying.  I am saying he is the one who is telling a lie.

I further put it to you that Mr Nosenga was at the Kwamadala hostel prior to the attack, that he did take part in the attack and that you and your co-applicants are for some reason covering up his existence at the hostel.

The way you talk it looks like you were staying there at Kwamadala hostel, then it means in that case I was not staying there.  You were the one who was staying there, because I'm telling you that Nosenga was not there and you insist that Nosenga was there.  It looks like you are the one who was staying at Kwamadala hostel.
I think, Mr Dlamini, what is intended to be put to you is that according to Matanzima Nosenga, he was staying at the hostel prior to the attack and that he was part of the attack, you've denied that.
Yes, I dispute that, he was not there and he was not present during the attack.
Did you see any police presence in Boipatong on the night of the attack?
He has answered that question, he said "no".

I have no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS TANZER
You gave instructions that stolen items be burnt.
Yes, that was the instruction that I was given by Damarra.
Did you steal any good from Boipatong on the night of the attack?

Thank you, Sir.
	Mr Dlamini, I take it that the meeting or the conference that was in Ulundi, where Mr Nosenga was brought to, was the annual conference of the IFP, am I right?
And that annual conference is the one that is held in July's annually, am I right?
And that is the very conference which was held after the Boipatong attack?
You say you were not there at the conference, you don't know what happened there, do you?
I was not there, I did not go to the conference.
Do you know what was said in the conference?
No, I do not know because I was not present.
Now, when Nosenga was speaking to you about his intention to plant bombs, did he tell you that he was present during the attack at Boipatong?
Did you find out from him?
No, we knew that he was not there.
How did you know that he was not there?

I've already mentioned that I was there at Kwamadala hostel.  Though I cannot be very sure about the month, I was still there, I was not yet arrested.  The other co-applicants were already arrested at the time.

No, Sir, what I want to be clear on is, you did not see Nosenga when he was arriving at the hostel, you were only told that there is a boy, or there is a  young man by the  name of Nosenga who says this and that?
What is being put to you is, do you know precisely when Nosenga arrived at the hostel.
He came on that particular day when these two gentlemen called us.

I have no further questions, thank you.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MAPOMA

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Dlamini, when Mr Nosenga told you and the many people who were you, that he had been sent by the ANC to plant bombs in Kwamadala hostel, I understand from your evidence that he was giving you this information freely and voluntarily, am I right?
I cannot say whether he was free to tell us because I was not the first person to see, he started speaking to these other guys.  I just saw him for a very shot time.

Wait a minute.
	Did you just say that he appeared as if he was not mentally sane?
He looked shocked, he seemed very shocked.
Please speak close so that the interpreter can interpret everything, because some of the things the interpreter is not interpreting.
Nobody was threatening Mr Nosenga, nobody was doing anything to Mr Nosenga to make him talk, am I right?
When I was there nothing happened.  I don't know before that but when I was there with him nothing like that happened.
And then after he had made this startling confession he was taken to the senior committee of the IFP in the hostel, is that right?
And he was left there in the hands of the senior committee?
Besides Mr Thembankosi Khumalo, who else was present when Mr Nosenga was left there?

Thembankosi was in his house, there were other people in his house.  He took him to the committee and I was not there at the time, but as we were taking him there, Thembankosi was in his house with his inmates.

So when you said in your evidence earlier
"We took Nosenga to the IFP Committee."
That's not correct, is it?
No, you took Mr Nosenga to Mr Khumalo, Mr Khumalo took Mr Nosenga to his committee.
Yes, Khumalo himself was the member of the committee.
Now, how long after that was Mr Nosenga taken to Ulundi?
Though I cannot remember very well, that took place some time ago.  I think it was about a week or two and he was taken there.
So what happened for that one or two-week period, between the time after Mr Nosenga was taken to Mr Khumalo and the time that he was taken to Ulundi, what happened to Mr Nosenga?
Did you see him during that one or two-week period?
Yes, I saw him inside the hostel.
I used to see him sitting in front of one room that was occupied by the group from the township.  Most of the times he would be there.
He was associating with other people in the hostel quite freely during that period?
I can say so because he was staying with us inside the hostel.
Is that the treatment that was usually meted out to ANC spies, they were accommodated in the hostel and allowed to move around freely?
If the person would be there among us and be free, we would give him accommodation but if he would try to hide himself, we wouldn't help him by giving accommodation.
At that stage you and none of the other hostel residents, besides the senior committee, knew what was going to happen to Mr Nosenga, am I right?
How do you know he was taken to Ulundi?
A meeting was convened just before the trip to Ulundi and it was mentioned that he would be leaving with the people going to Ulundi.
It was Mr Khumalo, Thembankosi Khumalo.  He told us that this man would be taken with to Ulundi.
Was this a meeting held in the stadium, a meeting of all the residents of the hostel?
So there would have been hundreds and hundreds of people present when the announcement was made that Mr Nosenga is being taken to Ulundi?
Yes, there was a large number of people when the meeting was held.
Was Mr Mkhize at that meeting?
I've already mentioned that my co-applicants were already arrested, he knows nothing about Nosenga.
So the answer is, Mr Mkhize was not at that meeting?
Was Prince Vanana Zulu at that meeting?
How long had Mr Nosenga been at the hostel before he was taken to Mr Khumalo?
I cannot lie, I cannot remember.
I cannot even estimate, I cannot remember.
Mr Nosenga must have, on your version, must have come to the hostel almost immediately after the Boipatong attack, would that be right?
So would you say that is was public knowledge, everyone at the hostel knew Mr Nosenga, and everyone knew that Mr Nosenga was a man who had been sent by the ANC to plant bombs in the hostel?
Other people who were with me in the hostel knew, except the people who were already arrested.
What did Mr Khumalo say at that meeting was going to happen to Mr Nosenga in Ulundi, why was he being taken to Ulundi?

Though he did not mention the reason, he first mentioned something about the truth, the truth that would be taken.  And he later mentioned that even this young man who was there to plant the bombs would be taken with to Ulundi.
Mr Nosenga wasn't going to conference as a delegate I take it, he was going to conference as an exhibit, am I right?  He was going to be presented to the leaders at conference.
Yes, I think he was there as an exhibit from Kwamadala hostel.
As an ANC spy who had been sent by the ANC to blow up the hostel.
And this conference in Ulundi was addressed by the top leadership of the IFP at the time, am I right, including Chief Mangasotho Buthelezi?
Though I was not there, I think it was like that.
Can you explain why Chief Buthelezi has said in the media that he knows nothing about this Mr Nosenga?
Are you talking about the Buthelezi in the Committee or someone else?

Sorry, Mr Berger, the man wasn't at the meeting, how can he explain anything about what might have happened in Mr Buthelezi's mind or why he would deny something?  He doesn't know whether the man was actually presented to him or not, it's not a fair question.

Thank you, Mr Lax, I will rephrase the question.
	Who else besides Mr Khumalo and Mr Nosenga went to the conference at Ulundi?
Will you please repeat the question?
I'm talking about the delegation from ...(intervention)
What you are being asked is, apart from Nosenga and Mr Khumalo, who else went to Ulundi.

The people who went to the conference, I heard that it was Vincent Khanyile, Vincent Khanyile was one of them and Prince Zulu was one of them too, Bazuka and the others, quite a number of people although I cannot remember the other names.
Well I'd like you to think hard about who the people were who went to Ulundi.  You were at a meeting ...(intervention)
Mr Berger, do you want him to give us all the names of the persons who went to Ulundi?
Can you recall the names of all the person who went to Ulundi?
I've already said that I cannot remember the others.
Are there any of the people who are your co-applicants here, who went to Ulundi?
Is he the only one amongst the co-applicants?
Yes, among my co-applicants he is the only one that I know did go to Ulundi.
Besides your co-applicants - well, are you saying that all your co-applicants besides Mr Vincent Khanyile were arrested at the time of the Ulundi conference?
Yes, there are others with whom I was arrested.  We were arrested in groups, we were not arrested all at once.
Well let me ask you about Qambelani Buthelezi, Bhekinkosi Mkhize and Victor Mthembu, had they all been arrested by the time of the Ulundi conference?
Buthelezi was already arrested, Mkhize as well, Victor was arrested together with myself.
And Victor Mthembu never went to Ulundi to the conference?
I cannot remember very well as to whether he attended the conference or not.
And then after the conference, Mr Nosenga was brought back to the hostel.
And what report-back did you receive from Mr Khumalo or any other delegate to the conference, as to what had happened in Ulundi in relation to Mr Nosenga?
They did not tell me anything.

What was the status then of Mr Nosenga?  Here was a man who had come to plant bombs in the hostel, the allegation was important enough for him to be taken off to Ulundi to the national conference, this had been announced at a public meeting in the stadium, and he comes back to the hostel and there is no report-back to the hostel dwellers about what has been decided to be done with Mr Nosenga.
It might as well be that something was said in my absence.  Yes, that is possible, something may have been said to the residents.
Well didn't you ask anyone about what happened to Nosenga in Ulundi, or what is his status now in the hostel, what are we to do with him?  Did you ask anyone?
No, I did not ask anyone.
You were just happy to have him back in the hostel and he walked around freely?
Yes, I just looked at him as one of the residents at the hostel.
I put it to you, Mr Dlamini, that your version about Mr Nosenga saying that he came to the hostel to plant bombs is absolute nonsense.
No, I know that to be the truth.
When you made your application for amnesty at page 211, 12 and 13, were you in prison?
You were taken to the police station in Vereeniging to have your application attested, is that right?
And you were accompanied by Mr Nana Tshabangu who acted as your interpreter, am I correct?
You have confirmed that the documents at pages 214 and 215 have been read to you and translated to you and you agree with the contents of those two pages, am I right?

In that document you say, or you agree with the statement which says that
"The attack was a warning to ANC supporters in Boipatong, not to support the Self Defence Units."
Do you agree with that?
The idea, you say, was to intimidate the residents of Boipatong in the same way as  you had been intimidated, do you agree with that?
How were you going to intimidate the residents of Boipatong?  How were you going to achieve that in the attack?
To intimidate them would mean attacking them, nothing else.
You also say that the political purpose of the attack on Boipatong was to teach Boipatong a lesson.  How were you going to teach Boipatong a lesson, what were  you going to do?
The lesson is beating them up, nothing else.
So who were you going to beat up?
The comrades.  Some fled but we managed to get hold of others.
But how were you going to teach the residents of Boipatong a lesson.  Leave aside the comrades, how were you going to teach the residents a lesson?
Those who had not been attacked have learnt a lesson to the effect that we can beat them up, that is the lesson.
So the purpose of the attack on Boipatong was to beat up all the residents of Boipatong, or as many of the residents as you could lay your hands on, am I right?
That was not the case.  It so happened but that was not the case.
So the purpose was only to attack the Self Defence Units, is that right?
And by attacking the Self Defence Units, you were going to teach the people of Boipatong a lesson?
And this was your instruction before you left the hostel, only attack the Self Defence Units, we are not going to attack the people of Boipatong, that right?
Even though that was not expressed as such, but I thought that when we went there we were looking for the boys who were burning people in the township.
Well then how was it expressed at the meeting before you left, what were your instructions?

At the meeting on the 17th if was said that the day has arrived, let us go now to Boipatong.  Each one of us men were ordered to go and fetch our weapons, such as knopkierries.  I was already armed.  Only a few went back to their rooms, but most of them had already armed themselves.
You did not attend any meeting prior to the 17th, at which the possibility of an attack on anybody, whether in Boipatong or anywhere else, was discussed, am I right?
No, I did not attend any such meetings.
There was no meeting at which you were present, where there was talk of attack at all, am I right?
And yet when the siren went off on the 17th of June 1992, you knew to go to the stadium with your weapon, why?

I want you to understand this very well, Mr Berger, when this siren went off I was in another room where we were drinking and when I left on my way to the stadium I came across Kwesele Zingene(?) and he said I should go back to my room and arm myself.
And the other residents who came, you don't know why they came out?
On leaving their rooms, they were responding to the siren that was summoning us to the stadium, to the arena.
So there was nothing said at the meeting of the 17th, about attacking the Self Defence Units, am I right?
Now you say you entered Boipatong, and I'm reading from your affidavit at page 222, and you were chasing the SDUs.

Then you say
"They ran away and one ran into a house.  There was a man who tried to run away and I stabbed him with a spear.  That man jumped over a fence and he disappeared."
Now that man, was he an SDU member?
Even though I would not be certain what he was, but I think so.
So he was a young man?
That is correct, he was a youth but he was not young.
That's the first man you stabbed, correct?

Then you say
"We continued.  We got into a house.  Themba was with me and there were children there who were crying."
Is that Themba Mabote?

That is correct.
MR BERGER
"I asked the child: 'where are your parents'?"
That is correct.
No, I saw only one, not two children.
Well you said the children were crying, you say there was more than one child, so how many children were crying?
Maybe you did not get me well, I did not say they were crying in this house, I am saying they were crying in houses.  In the house that I entered I only found one child.

Mr Dlamini, please listen to what you have confirmed under oath and confirmed again this morning. 	After this man has jumped over the fence and disappeared, this is what you say
"We continued.  We got into a house.  Themba was with me.  Children were crying there.  I asked the child: "where is your parents'?"
Yes, that is correct, I did ask where the parents were but I was asking one child.  Maybe you do not understand me quite well.
And you say the children were not crying in that house, they were crying somewhere else?

And then you say
"Boom, boom."
That is correct.
Is that the name of Thembiso Kubeka?
And that is applicant number 18.  He's one of your co-applicants, am I right?

Yes, he is present.
MR BERGER
"He then stabbed the child with a spear."
Am I right?
So you asked the child: "where are your parents?", and before the child could answer, Sthembiso Kubeka stabbed the child with a spear.
Was the child a boy or a girl?
I think it was a boy if I'm not mistaken.
I don't want to attempt to lie, he was this high.  I cannot tell his age.
You indicate a very small child, a very small boy.
I don't anything about metres, I don't want to tell you a lie.
I'm just confirming what you've indicated in Court.  Where did Sthembiso Kubeka stab this child, where on his body?
I think he stabbed him at the back because the child was facing me.  I think it was somewhere behind his back.
I think it was once because when he stabbed him once the child cried and I fled.
Then you go on - well, let me ask you, you couldn't have thought that this child was a member of an SDU, am I right?
No, I did not think it like that.
So there was absolutely no reason for this child to be stabbed?
No, there was no reason.  Had I thought about that, it would have been me who stabbed him.
It was a child.  I was not stabbing children that young, I wanted all the people, the ones who were troublesome, burning people around, not children.
Did you say anything to Sthembiso Kubeka?
No, I did not say anything, there was no time for conversations really, we were in a hurry.
Did you try to stop him?  The child was between you and him, he was behind the child, you were in front of the child, you saw him lift up the spear, did you try and stop him from stabbing the child?
I was talking to the child on my knees, I only heard the child crying and when I raised my head I saw this spear being pulled from the child.
You actually saw the spear being pulled out of the child by Sthembiso Kubeka?

Then you go on
"I stabbed another person, a man, with a spear in the vicinity of Shlube Street.  I don't know what happened to that person.  We then left the township and returned to the hostel."
According to your statement you stabbed two people, according to your evidence before this Committee you say you stabbed about four people, why didn't you mention the other two in your statement?

Maybe the person who was interpreting did not get me well.
